entry.title: Process Atoms: Towards AI-Powered Business Process Management
entry.content:
1- Introduction

Business Process Management (BPM) emerged in the 20th century as a response to the growing need for organizations to combine evolving management practices with technological innovation to optimize business operations across industries. 

Throughout its history, BPM has undergone several transformative shifts. The first era focused on process modeling, where organizations documented “as-is” and “to-be” processes to create transparency and standardization. This approach helped visualize processes but often remained static and disconnected from real execution. 

The second era introduced process mining, driven by the complexity of modern enterprises. It was no longer enough to know the ideal process design; companies needed to understand how processes actually ran, uncover bottlenecks, and identify opportunities for improvement based on real data. 

Now, BPM is entering a pivotal new phase: the knowledge-driven era, powered by AI and intelligent automation. As AI becomes part of the workforce, traditional business processes are starting to show cracks, not because systems fail, but because the way we define and communicate processes is outdated. Today, humans and machines need a shared language to understand exactly what should happen, when, and why. It needs a context and it needs to reflect the intention. 

For decades, business intent has been locked inside scattered documents and rigid diagrams that quickly drift away from reality. To move forward, we need a new foundation, one that captures process knowledge in a clear, structured, and machine-readable way.  

The foundation is Process Atoms. 

2- The Three Eras of Process Transformation and the New Frontier 

As Dr. Gero Decker (General Manager SAP Signavio and founder) highlighted at the SAP Transformation Excellence Summit in The Hague (October 2025), the evolution of BPM can be traced through three major eras, each defined by a different core artifact and analytical capability. Understanding this trajectory explains why a fourth frontier is now emerging. 

Era 1 - Model-Driven Process Management 

Core artifact: centrally managed process models 

Organizations first focused on manually documenting how work is or should happen. With BPMN, flowcharts, and collaborative modeling platforms, teams aligned on standardized processes. This brought transparency but models remained static, manual, and quickly outdated. 

Era 2 - Data-Driven Process Analytics 

Core artifact: centrally managed event data 

The rise of process mining shifted attention to how work actually happens. Event data utilized to discover as-is process models revealed deviations, bottlenecks, throughput times, and patterns invisible in traditional models. This era brought objectivity and evidence but lacked operational decision context. 

Era 3 - Knowledge-Driven and AI-Powered Transformation 

Core artifact: process and decision knowledge 

The third era marks the shift from analyzing processes to enabling them to understand and act using contextualized knowledge. In this era, processes become intelligent systems that interpret context (e.g., high-risk vs. low-risk customers), business intent (e.g., fraud prevention vs. speed), operational decisions (e.g., when to escalate a claim), rules and constraints (e.g., mandatory approvals), dependencies (e.g., documentation required before shipment), semantics (e.g., linking “credit note” to “invoice correction”), and real operational signals (e.g., detecting missed SLAs). This deep understanding is essential as AI agents join the workforce and processes become hybrid human–agent systems. To operate safely, adaptively, and explainably, AI needs granular, contextual building blocks of process knowledge, so it can make accurate decisions, avoid costly errors, and ensure compliance while improving efficiency. 

The New Frontier: Hybrid Processes 

As AI agents begin to participate directly in operational work, processes are evolving into hybrid human–agent systems. This introduces new requirements: 

  • Richer observability (machines and humans must understand what is happening) 
  • Stronger explainability (AI must communicate why it made a decision or took an action providing transparency into the logic, rules and data behind) 
  • Unified process knowledge layer (shared behavioral and decision knowledge across humans, systems, and agents) 
  • Integrated process and decision intelligence (where operational decisions matter as much as strategic and tactical ones) 

To combine all these requirements, Hybrid processes demand a new building block, one that captures behavior, decisions, context, and meaning in a unified way. This is exactly the role of Process Atoms. 

3- Process Atoms: The Foundation of the New Frontier 

As we enter the knowledge-driven, AI-powered frontier of process transformation, we need a way to represent enterprise behavior that is precise, contextual, measurable, and usable by both humans and intelligent systems. This is why we are re-establishing the definition of Process Atoms: 

Process Atoms are (A) meaningful building blocks of enterprise behavior that serve as (B) the foundation for process and decision intelligence. They are (C) semantically rich, (D) observable, and (E) context-bound. 

Process Atoms provide the structural layer that enables hybrid processes, where humans, systems, and AI agents must all understand, reason about, and execute behavior safely and consistently.  

Below is what each part of the definition means and why it matters: 

(A) Meaningful Building Blocks of Enterprise Behavior: Just like Lego bricks, Process Atoms are the essential, basic units that can be combined in various ways to construct complex structures. Each brick has a defined shape and purpose, much like Process Atoms carry specific business behaviors that are meaningful and integral to the bigger picture. 

Process Atoms capture actual units of enterprise behavior such as actions, decisions, checks, obligations, validations, handovers, state changes, business events, or overall declarative constraints. They are “meaningful” because each atom represents something that matters to how the business operates and can be independently understood, reused, or verified. 
By breaking processes into meaningful, modular components, Process Atoms make behavior reusable across variants, visible for governance, and consumable by AI without relying on monolithic diagrams or vague descriptions. 

Example: 
“Verify invoice completeness before three-way match.” 

(B) The Foundation for Process and Decision Intelligence: Similar to the foundational base plate you start with when building a Lego set, Process Atoms serve as the groundwork upon which process and decision intelligence is built. Without these foundational pieces, the structure (the organization's processes and decision-making frameworks) would be unstable and partly incomplete. 

Processes and decisions are inseparably linked yet historically treated as separate disciplines. Process Atoms unify them: a Process Atom may represent a behavioral step (“validate invoice”), a rule (“apply tolerance of 2%”), or a decision (“route to manual review”). 
This makes Process Atoms the common substrate for: 

  • process intelligence (mining, conformance, simulation) 
  • decision intelligence (rule evaluation, decision automation, governance) 
  • AI reasoning (recommendations, planning, orchestration) 

Instead of stitching together multiple artifacts, Process Atoms give AI, humans, and systems one consistent knowledge layer. 

Example: 
“Apply fast-track approval when order value < €5,000 and customer is premium.” 

(C) Semantically Rich: Like specialty Lego pieces that add detail and unique characteristics to a model, semantically rich Process Atoms carry detailed, nuanced information that provides deeper understanding and context within enterprise operations. 

An atom carries structured meaning: 

  • entities involved 
  • intent and purpose 
  • conditions, constraints, dependencies 
  • pre/post behavior 
  • domain semantics 
  • relationships to other Process Atoms, process models, decision models, analytical dashboards, etc. 

Since AI agents cannot safely operate on vague descriptions, semantics provide the clarity and explicitness required for machines and humans to interpret behavior in the same way. 

Example: 
“Match goods receipt quantity to PO within ±2% tolerance.” 

(D) Observable: Just as Lego instructions provide a clear, step-by-step guide that lets you see and understand each phase of the construction, and monitor and control the building process, Process Atoms enable organizations to track and monitor their processes, offering a clear view of how each part interacts and functions within the larger system.  

Process Atoms are tied to real operational signals like events, timestamps, states, or data patterns. They can be checked, monitored, validated, and traced in actual execution. 
This closes the gap between “how we think the process works” and “what actually happens.” Observability enables conformance checking, continuous monitoring, SLA validation, compliance verification, and explainability of agent actions among others. 

Example: 
“Acknowledge ticket within 1 hour of submission.” 

(E) Context-Bound: Just like certain Lego bricks only function effectively when placed in specific parts of a model or set, Process Atoms are context-bound, meaning they are relevant and applicable within specific scenarios or environments within an organization. They depend on their contextual placement to fulfill their intended role effectively. 

Process Atoms are not abstract; they are anchored in the conditions that shape behavior like region, regulation, customer segment, risk level, product type, etc. 
Context ensures that Process Atoms behave correctly across variations and prevents AI systems from applying rules or actions blindly. Context ensures processes remain situationally correct, not universally generic. 

Example: 
“For EU shipments, capture export documentation before dispatch.” 

4- Flexible Types, Multiple Purposes 

Not all Process Atoms look the same or serve the same purpose. Depending on the use case, different attributes, metadata, and consumption formats may be required. There is no rigid checklist; Process Atoms flex based on intent and application. Some are behavioral, decisional, or temporal; others express obligations, analytics, or agent guardrails. This flexibility allows Process Atoms to adapt to the process, the domain, and the consumer, whether human, system, or AI agent. 

However, beneath this flexibility lies a set of key structural principles that define how an atom is built. No matter the use case, every atom follows a tiered architecture: 

Figure 1: Process Atoms Types

  • The Activity Core: At the center of every atom is an Activity. Since Process Atoms represent enterprise behavior, they must relate to a fundamental unit of work. Without this foundation, there is no behavior to measure. At its simplest, an atom confirms the presence or absence of an activity. The first layer of logic adds Process Flow constraints, such as sequential relations (Direct or Indirect) and cardinalities. 
    • Example: “If Change Price occurs then Number of Change Price occurrences <= 2”). 
  • Contextual Attributes: The next layer introduces Context, making the atom "context-bound." This is driven by three attribute types: Temporal (e.g., Timestamp, Duration), Resource (e.g., User Role, Organizational Unit, machines, agents), and Data Attributes (e.g., PO amount, Country, Document Type). 
    • Example: “If PO Created occurs, then either PO Approved or PO Rejected occurs. AND Time from PO Created to PO Rejected OR PO Approved <= 48H” 
  • Composition & Multi-Attribute: The advanced layers use Boolean logic (AND, OR, NOT) to combine fragments into complex constraints and combinations of contextual attributes. 
    • Example: “If PO Created occurs then either PO Approved or PO Rejected occurs AND Time from PO Created to PO Rejected or PO Approved <= 48H AND PO Created.amount <= 100k €” 
  • Finally, the Multi-Object layer allows Process Atoms to describe relationships across diverse business objects, aligning perfectly with Object-Centric Process Mining (OCPM). 
    • Example: “If PO Created occurs then either PO Approved or PO Rejected occurs AND PO Created.amount <= 100k € AND PO.items.count <= 10” 

By following these principles, Process Atoms remain small and explicit while capturing the rich complexity of modern business operations. 

5- How Process Atoms Can be Used (Selective Examples Across Use Cases) 

(A) Analytics & Conformance Checking 

Process Atoms provide precise definitions of expected behavior, which can be matched against event logs to check for compliance with rules, adherence to SLAs, process deviations, behavioral patterns, and etc. 

Example: “Invoice approval must happen within 24 hours, by a manager, for invoices over €10K before posting” becomes an observable atom that process mining capability can validate across thousands of cases and report on the appeared violations. 

Core Value Proposition: Mitigating evolution debt & model rigidity and solving fragmented intent through guided analysis. By decoupling logic from flow, atoms address the limitations of rigid BPMN models. This allows for flexible, end-to-end rule enforcement without the need to manually redesign complex, brittle diagrams for every new condition or path variation. Additionally, by providing a semantically rich layer for investigation. It transforms raw event data into a guided narrative, allowing analysts to move beyond intuition and navigate complex enterprise behaviors through structured, logical reasoning.  

(B) Explainability of Process Behavior 

Because Process Atoms are textual and semantically rich, they can be used to explain: 

  • How does a process work? 
  • What business rules apply?
  • Why was a decision made? 
  • How does an AI agent interpret a step? 
  • How do human resources perform tasks? 

Example: 
An agent can explain its action: “I escalated this claim because the atom ‘Escalate when claim >€5,000 without documentation’ applied.” 

Core Value Proposition: Transforming Raw Data into Guided Business Reasoning. This addresses the Fragmentation of Process Intent by providing a semantic layer that explicitly explains the logic behind every operational event. It replaces manual, intuition-based investigation with a guided analytical path, allowing users to instantly understand the "why" behind complex process behaviors and significantly accelerating the path to insight.

(C) Guardrails & Context for AI Agents 

Process Atoms define what an agent can do, when, and under what constraints. They ensure AI behaves safely within the process. 

Example: 
An AI assistant knows: 

  • It must request additional documents for high-risk customers 
  • It must not skip approvals over a certain threshold 
  • It must provide confirmation within SLA windows 

Because Process Atoms encode these boundaries explicitly. 

Core Value Proposition: Opportunity for rapid, reliable agent enablement. This addresses the Absence of Machine-Readable Guardrails by allowing organizations to reuse modular process context for agent creation. This significantly reduces "time-to-code" while ensuring that agents operate with high reliability and safety within governed boundaries. 

(D) Workflow Automation & Orchestration 

Workflow engines can consume Process Atoms as executable logic fragments or triggers. Process Atoms can be translated into automation tasks, decision tables, validation steps, signals that drive actions, and dynamic workflow branching. 

Example: 
A workflow system receives a Process Atoms that states: “If delivery is overdue by 24 hours, notify the customer.” 
This becomes an automation rule without needing a full BPMN redesign. 

Core Value Proposition: Addressing the scalability gap in logic discovery. This seizes the opportunity to operationalize intent at scale. By treating atoms as modular triggers, organizations can implement rapid automation updates and dynamic branching without the heavy overhead of modifying the underlying core workflow architecture. 

In summary: 

Process Atoms provide the knowledge foundation required for the next frontier of AI-powered process transformation: hybrid human–agent processes. Without process atoms in today’s hybrid and complex process landscape, knowledge remains fragmented across BPMN models, rule engines, documentation, and tribal knowledge, making it impossible for AI to reason holistically. 

Process Atoms make enterprise behavior granular, understandable, explainable, and operationally safe. By being meaningful, intelligent, semantic, observable, and context-aware, Process Atoms enable both humans and AI agents to collaborate in processes with shared understanding. 

Stay tuned as you will hear more about Process Atoms in the near future, ranging from product updates and thought leadership to conceptual discussions on how the very nature of process management is further changing.

entry.title: Re: Display PDF. Note etc.. found in the table SRGBTBREL...
entry.content:
SRGBTBREL does not store the document itself. It only stores the relationship between a business object (PO, material, etc.) and an attachment (GOS, SAPoffice, URL, ArchiveLink). That’s why you can’t “download from SRGBTBREL” directly.

What you must do depends on the attachment type (SRGBTBREL-TYPEID_B / CATID_B).

If the attachment is ArchiveLink (PDF in content server)
→ Use SCMS_URL_GENERATE or WEB_BDS_BUILD_URL_FOR_AL
This only works if ARCHIV_ID and ARC_DOC_ID exist (TOA01/02/03 entries).
SRGBTBREL alone is not enough.

If the attachment is SAPoffice / GOS (EXT, RAW, ATTA)
→ Use SO_DOCUMENT_READ_API1
This is the correct and standard way.

entry.title: Re: Vendor notes and Attachments data migration from ECC...
entry.content:
Migrating vendor notes and attachments directly by loading tables like SRGBTBREL or SOOD is not recommended in S/4HANA. These tables are technically managed by GOS/SAPoffice and ArchiveLink, and direct inserts can lead to inconsistencies and missing links.

The right and supported approaches are:

• Do not use LSMW – it is obsolete for S/4HANA and not suitable for attachments.
• Do not load SRGBTBREL / SOOD directly – SAP does not support this.

entry.title: Re: Is there any datasource, which bring field of table S...
entry.content:
• SRGBTBREL belongs to Generic Object Services (GOS).

  • GOS is a technical framework for relationships (attachments, notes, URLs) between business objects.

  • SAP does not provide standard extractors/datasources for such technical tables, because they are not considered business-relevant reporting data.

What you can do instead (if you really need the data):

  • Create a custom BW extractor (generic datasource on table/view or ABAP-based extractor).

  • Build a CDS view (S/4HANA) joining SRGBTBREL with business object keys (e.g. vendor, PO, material).

  • Extract attachments via application logic (e.g. GOS APIs) rather than directly reporting on the table.

entry.title: Re: Table SRGBTBREL not getting updated in S/4 system wit...
entry.content: In S/4HANA this is expected behavior. SAP has redesigned the attachment framework and you should not rely on SRGBTBREL being updated anymore. Attachments are now mainly handled via KPro / ArchiveLink and accessed through APIs and services, which is why ARCHIV_GET_CONNECTIONS still returns data even though SRGBTBREL stays empty. The data is recorded, just not persisted in that table. For custom reports, SAP recommends using standard GOS classes or ArchiveLink/KPro APIs instead of reading SRGBTBREL directly.

entry.title: Re: GOS linking Order
entry.content: To identify PM orders that have GOS attachments and show this in IW38, you can use table SRGBTBREL, which stores the relationships between business objects and attachments. For PM orders, the business object key is the order number. The link is done by joining AUFK-AUFNR with SRGBTBREL-INSTID_A (or INSTID_A depending on release), as this field contains the object key of the linked business object. Once this join is in place, you can determine whether an order has attachments by checking the existence of corresponding entries in SRGBTBREL. This allows you to enhance IW38 reporting logic or build a custom report that flags orders with attachments.

entry.title: Differences in Labor Cost Calculations in Process Orders
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I hope you are doing well.

We are currently facing an issue with labor cost calculations in process orders, and I would really appreciate your support or insights if anyone has encountered a similar situation.

When comparing the costs calculated by the system versus the expected values, we have identified slight differences that occur only for labor activities.

Issue Description;

  • For the labor activity HHTA, the configured rate is 16,104 COP.

  • However, the system appears to be calculating the cost using an effective rate of 16,000 COP.

  • As a result:

    • Expected value: 98,234 COP

    • System-calculated cost: 97,600 COP

A similar behavior is observed for another labor activity (HHEM), where the calculated values are also slightly lower than expected.

As shown in the cost breakdown of the process order, these differences directly impact the total actual costs.

What we haved already checked

  • There are no rounding or truncation settings configured intentionally.

  • Labor rates and calculation formulas have already been reviewed and validated.

  • The issue occurs only for labor activities.

  • Other cost components, such as energy costs and overhead (CIF), are calculated correctly and match the expected values.

  •  

In addition, we have noticed that the total actual costs are not being summed correctly, apparently due to the discrepancies in labor cost calculations.

Questions to the community:

  1. Is there any standard SAP behavior that could cause labor rates to be implicitly rounded or truncated during cost calculation?

  2. Could this be related to time unit conversions, internal decimal handling, activity price determination, or cost element configuration?

  3. Are there any specific settings (e.g., cost centers, activity types, or process order costing) that should be reviewed to avoid this behavior?

  4. Why would this issue affect only labor activities and not other cost components?

Any guidance, references, or similar experiences would be highly appreciated.

Thank you very much in advance.

entry.title: Re: SAP CAP Lessons Learned: Reject error message missing on HTML5 Repository app?
entry.content:
Lucas, 

According to the standards, you should use HTTP 5XX for unhandled errors, for example: timeouts, database disconnections, etc.

While 4XX should be used for: unauthorized users, invalid data, and violations of business rules (which is precisely our case).

Regards, Victor.

entry.title: Re: Review and Adapt Business Roles after a Major Upgrade in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Hi @George_Yu1 ,

I am a big fan of your blog posts; they have been incredibly helpful.

I have a follow-up question regarding the sequence of tasks before and after upgrades across the Development (D), Test (T), and Production (P) tenants. In your post, 'Review Business Role Changes before a Major Upgrade,' you mentioned that deprecated Business Catalogs should be replaced via transports across D/T/P before the upgrade hits the Test tenant.

Could you clarify if this is considered a 'make a change' mentioned by both of you and the first poster. Additionally, regarding the activities after the T-tenant upgrade: should the testing of new features be categorized as a Post-Upgrade Test or simply a manual confirmation(because users' requirements are not reflected as changes yet). I am trying to understand the policy of biz role/catalogs update and change after upgrade.

I am finding the distinction between tasks across the tenants slightly confusing, especially since changes must originate in the D-tenant. It seems that 'real' changes and regression testing can only happen after the D and P tenants are upgraded.

Could we clarify the specific tasks occurring inside and outside the tenants? Here is my current understanding—could you please validate or correct this?

  • Pre-T-Tenant Upgrade:
    • Reviewing Release Notes/What’s New Viewer.
    • Question: when would we know the catalogs would be deprecated? Why must deprecated catalogs be replaced at this specific stage?
  • T-Tenant Upgrade Period:
    • Performing basic smoke tests (since configuration changes shouldn't originate in T).
  • Post-D/P-Tenant Upgrade:
    • Implementing changes based on requirements and new release features.
    • Executing PUT (Post-Upgrade Tests) and full Regression Testing.
    • Transporting finalized changes from D to T and P.

Thank you.

entry.title: Re: RSIRPIRL "Document has no content"
entry.content: RSIRPIRL shows “Document has no content” even though the document opens fine because the content server never actually delivers the file to the new repository. This almost always happens with larger documents and is not a GOS, SRGBTBREL, or DMS table issue. The root cause is HTTP/IIS size limits on the SAP Content Server. When RSIRPIRL or RSCMSTH2 requests a large file, IIS blocks the request (timeout / 404), so RSIRPIRL assumes the document has no content.

entry.title: Re: Using RSIRPIRL to convert SOFFPHIO class documents
entry.content:
Your strategy works because SOFFPHIO documents are category-driven, not repository-driven. By switching the category and then using RSIRPIRL, you are cleanly moving both existing and future documents without breaking references.

Key practical confirmations and tips based on real usage:

  • Defining the new category in the customer namespace (Z*) is mandatory. SAP standard SOFF* categories should not be reused for custom repositories.

  • Setting the new category via SKPR08 ensures that new SOFFPHIO documents immediately go to the new content repository.

  • RSIRPIRL is the correct tool to migrate existing documents between categories that point to different repositories.

  • Using DATUM (based on SOFFPHIO-CREA_TIME) is the safest way to control volume and run parallel jobs without overlap.

  • OAOR is the right transaction to validate category and repository assignment after migration.

  • Documents originally in SOFFDB can also be migrated the same way; once verified, SOFFCONT1 reorganization can safely reclaim database space.

  • Ensure SDOKPROF-USEHTTPPLG = OFF during the migration to avoid unexpected behavior when converting HTTP-based categories.

entry.title: Re: GET DATA FROM KPRO after RSIRPIRL
entry.content:
After RSIRPIRL, the error “GET DATA FROM KPRO / SCMS_DOC_READ_FILES” occurs when the system still tries to read the document from the old storage category (SOFFDB) instead of the new HTTP/DMS category (SOFFHTTP / ZSOFFHTTP).

What to check and fix:

  • Verify that RSIRPIRL actually finished successfully for the affected documents (no short dump, no cancelled job).

  • Check table SOFFPHIO for the document ID:

    • Field STOR_CAT must point to the new storage category, not SOFFDB.

    • If it still shows SOFFDB, the relocation did not complete correctly.

  • Use report DMS_KPRO_READ to test whether the file can be read directly from KPRO.

    • If this fails, the content was not migrated properly.

  • Ensure the new storage category is:

    • Correctly defined in OAC0 / OACT

    • Assigned via SKPR08

entry.title: Re: RSIRPIRL - some documents are not opening / migrating.
entry.content:
When RSIRPIRL migrates most documents but a few do not migrate or cannot be opened afterward, the issue is almost never the report itself. It is usually a content‑server or repository consistency problem.

What actually works in practice:

First, verify whether the problem documents really exist in KPRO.
Run DMS_KPRO_READ (or RSCMSTH2 for non‑DMS objects) for one failing document.
If the document cannot be downloaded there, RSIRPIRL cannot migrate it either.

Second, check the application log.
Go to SLG1 immediately after RSIRPIRL or after the CV03N error.
Typical errors are from SCMS_DOC_READ_FILES or HTTP 404 / timeout errors, which indicate the content server cannot deliver the file.

entry.title: Re: issue "Unexpected Error" with test run of SAP report...
entry.content:
In RSIRPIRL, the “Test run” is not a full dry‑run with detailed simulation output. It only checks whether the referenced SAPoffice/KPro entries are technically readable.
When it shows “Unexpected error”, it usually means the program encountered orphaned or corrupted SAPoffice records (for example entries in SOFFCONT1 / SOFFPHIO without physical content). This is exactly what SAP Note 1773722 describes.

Important points to understand:

• The test run does not list all affected documents and does not show migration results
• It stops validating individual entries as soon as corrupted content is detected
• This does not mean the report itself failed, but that data inconsistencies already exist

entry.title: Re: Migrate GOS items from SOFFCONT1 to Content Server us...
entry.content:
Yes, this behavior is expected. The size difference happens because SOFFCONT1 stores document content in the database using compression, while Content Server stores files uncompressed in the file system.

SOFFCONT1 is a cluster table and benefits from DB‑level compression (and sometimes additional SAPoffice compression). When RSIRPIRL migrates documents, it extracts the original binary content and writes it to the Content Server exactly as a physical file. During this process, no compression is applied, so the files grow to their real, uncompressed size.

RSIRPIRL does not migrate documents that are not referenced in SAPoffice tables. It strictly works on:

  • SOFFPHIO (physical objects)

  • SOOD / SOC3 metadata

  • Storage category selection (e.g. SOFFDB)

So the increase in size does not mean duplicate or extra documents were migrated. It only reflects the removal of database compression.

entry.title: Re: table SOFFCONT1 and report RSIRPIRL
entry.content:
RSIRPIRL does not allow selection of individual documents from SOFFCONT1 (like by DOC_ID or filename). By design, the report only works on storage category + time‑based selection, not on single records.

If you want to test with a small subset of documents, the only supported way is to limit by creation date/time. This is why the standard selection screen feels “too broad”.

SAP addressed this limitation via SAP Note 1536325.
After implementing this note, RSIRPIRL adds an additional date selection field, allowing you to restrict documents based on creation date (derived from SOFFCONT1 / SOFFPHIO timestamps). Using a narrow date range (for example, a single day or hour) effectively lets you test with just one or a few documents.

Recommended testing approach:

  • Implement SAP Note 1536325

  • Identify a test document’s creation date/time in SOFFCONT1

  • Use that date range in RSIRPIRL

  • Run first in test mode, then execute real migration

There is no supported way to manually pick a single SOFFCONT1 row directly in RSIRPIRL without this date-based restriction.

entry.title: Re: RSIRPIRL generate a hugh amount of folders
entry.content:
RSIRPIRL itself is not deciding how many folders are created.
When you migrate documents, RSIRPIRL only hands the content to KPro / SAP Content Server. The folder structure is then created internally by the content server (including SAP Content Server on EMC file archive).

The large number of folders is by design.

SAP Content Server distributes documents into many subfolders using a hash‑based directory logic to avoid file system limits and performance issues. This happens even if the repository was empty before migration. There is no supported setting to tell RSIRPIRL or the content server to place all documents into a single folder or to reduce the folder count.

entry.title: Re: Short Dump "System_NO_ROLL"
entry.content:
This short dump SYSTEM_NO_ROLL is a classic SAP memory exhaustion issue and the root cause is not the Infopackage logic itself, but runtime memory allocation failure during data load.

What is really happening:
The BW load starts fine, but while processing records it needs additional ROLL / swap memory. At some point the application server cannot allocate even a few KB (here 4004 bytes), so the work process terminates. That’s why the source system finishes successfully, but BW stops after only a few hundred records instead of lakhs.

entry.title: Re: SYSTEM_NO_ROLL - SAP Note 353579
entry.content:
ztta/max_memreq_MB is neither a user parameter nor an application system setting. It is a profile parameter, which means it must be maintained in the SAP instance profile.

To change it:

  • Go to RZ10

  • Select the Instance Profile (not DEFAULT.PFL)

  • Add or adjust parameter ztta/max_memreq_MB with an appropriate value (in MB)

  • Save and activate

  • Restart the SAP instance for the change to take effect

This parameter controls the maximum memory a single internal session (work process context) can allocate. If it’s too low, SAP throws SYSTEM_NO_ROLL dumps when large memory is requested (e.g., BW loads, large reports, RFCs).

So in short:

  • It is a profile parameter

  • Maintained via RZ10

  • Requires instance restart

  • Directly relevant for resolving SYSTEM_NO_ROLL dumps related to memory limits

This aligns exactly with SAP Note 353579 and standard Basis practice.

entry.title: Re: SYSTEM_NO_ROLL error only for 1 SAP ID
entry.content:
When SYSTEM_NO_ROLL occurs only for a single SAP ID, it is almost never a system‑wide memory configuration issue. If it were, all users running the same report with the same selection would fail. In these cases the root cause is user‑specific behavior during execution, not Basis parameters.

The most common reason is that the affected user is triggering a much larger in‑memory dataset during post‑processing, especially while exporting to Excel (ALV → spreadsheet). The dump typically occurs in classes like CL_SALV_BS_TT_ALVXML, which confirms the failure happens during XML/Excel generation, not during data selection. Even if the visible result list looks similar, user‑specific layouts, variants, hidden columns, totals, subtotals, or background formatting can drastically increase memory consumption.

entry.title: Re: UCMON Short dump - SYSTEM_NO_ROLL
entry.content:
This UCMON SYSTEM_NO_ROLL dump is genuinely a memory configuration issue, even if Basis says “physical memory is fine”. In SEM‑BCS / UCMON scenarios the problem is usually ABAP shared memory and roll/extended memory, not OS RAM.

What actually fixes it in practice:

The load from data stream creates large shared objects in ABAP memory. If abap/shared_objects_size_MB is too small, the task dumps every time after the first successful run. This is why it looks “not random” and why it fails consistently in UCMON.

Set and verify these parameters (RZ10 / RZ11, instance profile):

  • abap/shared_objects_size_MB → typically 200–300 MB (often missing entirely)

  • ztta/roll_extension → increase to realistic values (e.g. 200–500 MB)

  • ztta/roll_area → ensure it is not extremely low

  • em/initial_size_MB → check extended memory is sufficient

entry.title: Re: SYSTEM_NO_ROLL issue
entry.content:
SYSTEM_NO_ROLL during a BW process chain means the load step is requesting more memory than the ABAP runtime allows for a single internal session. This is very common in large PSA → Cube / DSO loads.

What actually works in practice:

  1. Check ztta/max_memreq_MB first (RZ11 / RZ10)
    This parameter limits how much memory one work process may consume.

    • Even if it is already near 2047 MB, the dump can still occur if the process needs contiguous memory.

    • This parameter alone is often not sufficient.

  2. Split the load into smaller packages (most effective fix)
    In the InfoPackage or DTP:

    • Reduce package size

    • Enable parallel processing (multiple smaller work processes instead of one huge one)

    This avoids one WP consuming all roll/extended memory.

  3. Check classic roll + extended memory parameters (Basis action)
    Ask Basis to review:

    • ztta/roll_extension

    • ztta/roll_first

    • em/initial_size_MB

    • abap/heap_area_dia

    • abap/heap_area_nondia

    Often the system has enough physical RAM, but memory is blocked by restrictive profile limits.

  4. Verify SAP Notes relevant to BW loads

    • SAP Note 1119924 – SYSTEM_NO_ROLL during load from data stream

    • SAP Note 353579 – ztta/max_memreq_MB behavior

entry.title: Re: SYSTEM_NO_ROLL dump in BW
entry.content:
In BW, a SYSTEM_NO_ROLL dump after a patch upgrade—especially when reports that previously ran in seconds now dump—usually means a memory parameter mismatch introduced by the upgrade, not missing application data.

In your case the key indicators are:

  • ztta/max_memreq_MB is already 2048 (so this alone is not the issue)

  • Only Generic Keys (Tables) is red in ST02

  • Problem started after kernel / SP upgrade

What typically goes wrong here is that roll/extended memory distribution is no longer balanced for BW workloads, even though the absolute limits look “correct”

entry.title: Re: SYSTEM_NO_ROLL - ztta/max_memreq_MB
entry.content:
When you use SAP Content Server (incl. with EMC File Archive), the folder structure is generated automatically by the Content Server. It uses a hash-based directory layout to:

  • Avoid file system limits

  • Improve performance

  • Prevent too many files in a single directory

This behavior is by design and not configurable via RSIRPIRL, DMS, or archive customizing.

Even if the archive was initially empty, the Content Server will still create many subfolders as soon as documents are stored. Trying to place all files into one folder would cause serious file system and performance issues and is not supported by SAP.

What you can do instead:

  1. Do not change folders at OS level – this will break the Content Server index.

  2. Check archive scalability:

    • Use multiple content servers or logical archive paths if needed.

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4Hana public Cloud - APIs availability to progr...
entry.content:
Regarding your inquiry about bank account integration, we would like to provide an update on the current SAP API capabilities.

Currently, SAP does not provide dedicated API functionality for Bank Accounts. However, APIs are available for Bank  information, which include the following details:

  • Bank: Basic identifiers such as Bank Number, BIC/SWIFT code, Bank Name, and Bank Branch.

  • Bank Address: Standard address fields for the default bank location.

  • BankScriptedAddress: International address versions identified by Address Representation Codes.

Please note that Bank Accounts differ from Banks in that they contain numerous key fields required to ensure consistency and uniqueness within the system. Due to these complexities, there are currently no available APIs to retrieve or update bank account information from external sources.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, workflow configurations must be transported between systems using specific SAP-provided applications. The transport method depends on the type of workflow content and your system landscape configuration.

Export Software Collection is the primary method for workflow content.

entry.title: Elevate from OData Provisioning Neo/Serverless Runtime(CF) to Integration Suite OData Provisioning
entry.content:
OData Provisioning exposes business data and business logic as OData services on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), thereby enabling customers to run user-centric applications on SAP Cloud.

In the Neo environment, OData Provisioning is available as a service of SAP BTP, which combines SAP Gateway capabilities in a Cloud context.

OData Provisioning, on Neo as a service, will no longer be accessible post December 31, 2028.
For more information, see SAP Note 3351844 

OData Provisioning, a new capability in Integration Suite

OData Provisioning functionality is now being provided as a capability on SAP Integration Suite. This facilitates exposing business data and logic from SAP Business Suite systems as OData services on SAP BTP. This in turn, allows customers to create and run user-centric applications seamlessly on SAP Cloud.

Refer this blog to know more about OData Provisioning Capability in SAP Integration Suite.

Supported plans for OData Provisioning in Integration Suite

OData Provisioning is available as a capability of SAP Integration Suite in all its plans. For details on SAP Integration Suite plans that support OData Provisioning, please refer SAP Note 2903776

How to migrate to OData Provisioning on Integration Suite?

  1. Transitioning OData Provisioning Service on Neo to OData Provisioning Capability in SAP Integration Suite
    Refer to this document for more detailed description on migration process.
    Note: You must re-register the services which were already registered to ensure business continuity.
  2. Transitioning OData Provisioning from SAP BTP  Serverless Runtime to SAP Integration Suite
    Follow this document for transition from using OData Provisioning functionality on SAP BTP, serverless runtime to SAP Integration Suite.
    Note: If the SAP Integration Suite subscription is in the same subaccount as the Serverless Runtime, the services which were already registered will appear in the Integration Suite application, and the runtime will work seamlessly.
    However, if the SAP Integration Suite subscription is in a different subaccount, then the services must be registered again for business continuity.

Common concerns raised by customers during migration

Scenarios:

  1. Your UI5/HTML5 application is developed using SAP Business Application Studio (BAS) with SAP managed approuter and consumes the OData Provisioning services, then the CSRF token handling for ‘modify’ operations are done at the application approuter level.
    In this case, to avoid any CSRF token validation failures from OData Provisioning, you would need to do the following steps:
    • In the xs-app.json file of your application remove parameter "csrfProtection"
    • Define prefix "/sap/opu" in backend destination of ui5.yaml
  2. You are using Principal Propagation scenario in the OData Provisioning Neo environment
    • By using AppToAppSSO authentication type between your application and OData Provisioning end point, then while migrating to CF environment, this type of destination should be changed to use authentication type as OAuth2JWTBearer or OAuth2UserTokenExchange
    • For more information on the destination authentication types on Neo and CF environment, refer this document.

entry.title: Quick Configuration Steps for Bulk Creation of External Users in SAP SuccessFactors LMS
entry.content:
Introduction of Bulk Creation of External User accounts in LMS:  

We manage external user accounts in SAP SuccessFactors Learning Management system (LMS). Which is critical for organizations that need to provide training access to external users. This document outlines two effective methods for creating external user accounts-admin-created accounts and user self -registration-along with the prerequisite configurations required for integration with Identity Authentication Services (IAS) and Identity Provisioning Services (IPS).

By following these steps, organizations can ensure secure access, streamlined onboarding and compliance with corporate learning standards.

Two Methods for External User Account Creation

  1. One approach we used via Admin-Created AccountsAdmin created user accounts in LMS directly via data import or User connector
  2. Another approach that we have users Self-Registration:

    • Admin sends user registration link and registration code (Site) via an email users to register themselves

      .

 

LMS Prerequisite Configuration Steps

Step 1 - Connector configuration settings
Goto System Administration → Configuration → System Configuration → CONNECTOR and set the following parameter as "Y" we need to choose always learning while using user connector

    • user.connector.defaultValue.lms-origin=Y

Here, Y = Learning, N = SuccessFactors Platform.

Step 2- Following step required when user Self-Registration

    • Users who self-registered for a Learning account using the “New user” flow and are active in Learning. This is only permitted if System Administration ->  Application Administration ->  User-Created Account -> Allow Users to create a new account at SuccessFactors Learning login page  User Settings is checked.

      • A user created directly in Learning (using the admin user interface, data import, or the user connector) and that created user doesn’t have a corresponding SuccessFactors Platform user record.
      • Users accessing an active site in Learning.

Step 3 - Global Application Settings 

    • we can select “Learning” in the Default user source system

 

Following steps are IAS/IPS Prerequisite Configuration

Initiate Identity Authentication Integration

Initiating Learning Identity Authentication Migration

Initiate integration of any organization' SAP SuccessFactors Learning system with the Identity Authentication service for SAP Cloud Identity Services so that we can use it for identity management

Navigate to: Admin Center → Upgrade Center → Optional Upgrades -> Select 

Initiate SAP Cloud Identity Services - Identity Authentication Integration for Learning-Only Users.

Note:

(The Initiate SAP Cloud Identity Services - Identity Authentication Integration for Learning-Only Users option will not be available until the Platform migration to Identity Authentication is activated)

Then click on Upgrade Now.

  • Once the upgrade process completes the status will change to Completed and the SuccessFactors platform administrator that initiated migration will receive an e-mail that the status has changed to Completed.

IAS/IPS admin will be able to help you with the following requested Identity Provisioning Steps

  1. Go to Identity Provisioning tenant.
  2. Under Target Systems → Transformations, update:
  3. "constant":"true",
  4. "targetPath":"$.sendMail",
  5. "scope":"createEntity"

we should ensure that the email notifications are sent during account creation.

Coming to LMS Configuration Steps

Step 1: Activate IAS Integration check point

  • In LMS  Go to:
    System Administration → Security → Activate Identity Authentication Integration.

    Here we can see the successful integration in between IAS and LMS

 

Step 2: Admin Create Site in LMS 

  • Go to:
    System Administration → Application Administration → Sites.

 

Step 3: Import list of external users using following import data user template

  • Goto :
    System Administration → System Management Tools → Import Data.
  • Download User Template, fill mandatory fields, and upload.
  • Key options:
    • Action: Select Import Data
    • Record Type: User
    • User Source System: Learning
    • Click on submit 
  • Following screen shots attached for your reference 

 

 

Goto LMS -> People ->here need to use the User Search to verify that the user source systems have been updated correctly the uploaded users 

 

Step 4: Email Activation

– Once import the external users into LMS, external users received the following email to activate their account and reset password. Below is the referenced test email screen shot.

Note: If users did not receive the above email, approach IAS/IPS consultant and run the job for external users

Step 5: We can "Reset Password" for created accounts

  • Users set their password via the activation link.

 

Step 6: Admin Assign Learning Items to created external users 

Step 1.Create Items, Libraries, and Assignment Profiles for external users.

execute updates in assignment profile , respective items automatically assigned to the user learning assignments

 

 

Step 7: Finally, Course Completion 

  • Once Users login into the LMS using the site and complete assigned courses and receive completion certificates like below referenced screen.

Step 8 : Same course completion data available in LMS ->Reports-> Learning History

Conclusion:

We are Implementing external user account creation in LMS requires careful planning and adherence to configuration best practices. Whether using admin-created accounts or user self-registration, organizations must ensure proper IAS/IPS integration, connector settings, and LMS configurations to maintain security and user experience. By completing these steps, external users can successfully access learning resources, complete assigned courses, and contribute to organizational learning goals
